newsitem.title: USA: U.S. West Coast gasolines firm with higher NYMEX.
newsitem.headline: U.S. West Coast gasolines firm with higher NYMEX.

text.p: Prices for U.S. West Coast gasoline strengthened with a higher futures market midday but distillates fell, traders said.
NYMEX October gasoline rose as much as 1.54 cents gallon to 64.50 cents, as a second set of U.S. inventory data showed gasoline drawdowns nationwide.
Gasoline stocks fell by 3.4 million barrels last week to 193.2 million barrels.
Traders noted that despite a 3.2 million barrel rise in Western stocks last week, distillates nationwide remained a significant 18 million below year-ago, according to the API.
But analysts early Thursday said distillate production in PADD 5 was up to last year's levels, despite trader fears of short supplies ahead of winter.
Locally, distillate inventories remained 715,000 barrels below year ago, at 10.9 million barrels, according to American Petroleum Institute data.
Traders said distillates were tight on lingering production problems at Arco and Mobil's Los Angeles refineries and Chevron's northern California plant.
They said a fluid catalytic cracker at the Mobil refinery was expected back late this week.
Traders reported that Chevron's Los Angeles refinery was due to shut a fcc later this week, but the company denied any maintenance was planned.
Los Angeles CARB diesel remained 76/77 cents a gallon, while "EPA," or low sulphur diesel slipped a half cent to 71/72 cents.
Jet fuel was seen ample out west, and stayed 76/77 cents overnight.
Los Angeles conventional-grade gasoline added a cent to reach 69/70 cents a gallon, with premium seen 7 cents higher.
Bids for CARB-grade unleaded in L.A. rose a quarter cent to 71.25 cents, while offers edged up 0.50 cent.
